bibl.title: Despatch from Robert S. Newton
Despatches from United States Consuls in St Paul Loanda

div1.p:
con-
sular duties to perform I should have waited the return of Mr. du Verge for an explanation, and also for an explanation in a matter of a personal nature which has recently come to light.
The facts of the case are these: on the arrival on the 3rd instant of the wrecked crew of the American whaler "Merlin", lost South of Mossamedes, I called at the house of Mr. T. Mark, a Swiss, holding a Dry Goods retailed shop, where Mr. Du Verge has hired a room as his residence and office. Mr. Mark who possesses the Key gave me permission to enter but would not permit me to lake the Ships Register as the Archives, he said, were left in his charge, and I am unable to register my correspondence in the proper official book which appeared to be locked away.
Wishing to take to my office the Ships Register did not appear to me any infraction of the Rules, or had Mr. Mark any official right or authority to interfere with me, for in the first place the room offered no facilities, for writing and in the
